video_caption: The video begins with a black screen, which then transitions to a scene featuring a MacBook Pro laptop on a wooden table. The laptop screen displays a question mark and the text "Unsupported Macintosh HD" indicating a boot issue. To the left of the laptop, there is a black and red external hard drive connected via a cable. The text "Steps start at 45 seconds" appears on the screen, suggesting that the video will provide troubleshooting steps for the issue. The video then shows the laptop screen turning off, leaving the screen black, and the external hard drive still connected to the laptop. The video concludes with the laptop screen remaining off, and the external hard drive still connected, indicating that the troubleshooting steps have not yet been initiated.

The video begins with a MacBook Pro laptop placed on a wooden table, its screen turned off. To the left of the laptop, there is a black external hard drive with a red accent, connected to the laptop via a USB-C cable. The scene is static, with no visible movement or action. The lighting is natural, suggesting the setting is indoors with ample daylight. The focus is on the laptop and the external hard drive, with no other objects or people in the frame. The video then shows a person's hands typing on the keyboard of the MacBook Pro, which is now displaying the Apple logo with a loading bar, indicating that the laptop is in the process of booting up. The external hard drive remains connected to the laptop, and the setting continues to be the same wooden table with natural lighting. The person's hands are the only visible movement, and the focus remains on the laptop and the external hard drive.

The video shows a MacBook Pro on a wooden table with a black screen displaying a white question mark and the text "Restarting..." in the center. To the left of the laptop, there is a black and red external hard drive connected via a USB-C cable. A person's hand appears and presses the power button on the laptop, causing the screen to go black momentarily before displaying a white icon of a disk with a loading bar underneath. The screen then shows a white error message with a circular arrow icon, indicating a system restart or recovery process. The environment is simple, with the focus on the laptop and the external hard drive, suggesting a troubleshooting or repair scenario.

The video shows a MacBook Pro laptop on a wooden table with a black screen displaying a white question mark and the text "Restarting..." in white. To the left of the laptop, there is a black and red external hard drive connected via a cable. A person's hand appears and presses the power button on the laptop, causing the screen to go black momentarily before displaying a white globe icon with a loading bar underneath, indicating the system is restarting. The environment is simple, with the focus on the laptop and the external hard drive, and the atmosphere suggests a troubleshooting or system recovery process.

The video begins with a MacBook Pro on a wooden table, displaying a login screen with a globe icon and a progress bar. A person's hand appears, pointing at the screen, then moves to the keyboard, pressing keys. The scene transitions to the person plugging in a USB cable into the laptop, with two external hard drives visible on either side. The laptop screen goes black, and the person presses the power button, causing the screen to display the macOS Utilities menu. The menu lists options such as "Restore From Time Machine Backup," "Reinstall macOS," "Get Help Online," and "Disk Utility." The video concludes with the person selecting the "Continue" option, indicating the start of a system recovery or repair process.

The video begins with a computer screen displaying the macOS Utilities interface, featuring options such as "Restore From Time Machine Backup," "Reinstall macOS," "Get Help Online," and "Disk Utility." The "Disk Utility" option is highlighted, indicating the user's intention to use this tool. The scene transitions to the Disk Utility application, where the "macOS Base System" disk image is shown with a capacity of 2.01 GB, 1.35 GB used, and 666.6 MB free. The user navigates through the Disk Utility interface, selecting different external drives and disk images, including "Time Machine Backup," "WD 2TB HD," "My Passport," and "Apple Disk Image." The video focuses on the detailed view of the "macOS Base System" disk image, displaying its mount point, capacity, available space, and device information. The user interacts with the Disk Utility interface, highlighting the "macOS Base System" disk image and exploring its properties. The video concludes with the user still engaged with the Disk Utility application, examining the "macOS Base System" disk image's details.

The video showcases a computer screen displaying the Disk Utility application on a Mac operating system. The focus is on a disk image named "macOS Base System," which is a macOS volume with a capacity of 2.01 GB. The disk image is mounted and shows a used space of 1.35 GB and a free space of 686.6 MB. The interface includes options for First Aid, Partition, Erase, Restore, and Unmount, with the First Aid tab currently selected. The screen also lists the mount point as "/", the type as "Disk Image Volume," and the connection as "Disk Image." The device is identified as "disk1s1." The background includes other volumes such as "WD My Passport_," "Time Machine," and "WD 2TB HD." The video remains static, with no changes or movements observed throughout the sequence.

The video begins with a close-up of a computer screen displaying the Disk Utility application, where the macOS Base System disk image is shown with its used and free space. The scene transitions to a wider view of a MacBook Pro on a wooden desk, with a person's hands visible as they plug in a USB drive. The focus then shifts to the Disk Utility window, highlighting the SanDisk Extreme SSD Media, a 1TB external drive. The person proceeds to erase the drive, selecting the format as "Mac OS Extended (Journaled)" and naming it "Boot Drive." The erasing process is shown with a progress bar, and the drive is successfully erased and formatted. The video concludes with the Disk Utility window displaying the newly formatted drive, ready for use.

The video begins with a view of the Disk Utility application on a computer screen, displaying a list of drives on the left side, including "WD My Passport," "Time Machine...," "WD 2TB HD," and "SanDisk Extreme 5SEAF Media." The main section of the screen shows details about the "SanDisk Extreme 5SEAF Media" drive, which is a 1TB USB external disk with a GUID Partition Map. The drive is labeled as the "Boot Drive" with a capacity of 999.83 GB. The interface includes options for "First Aid," "Partition," "Erase," "Restore," and "Mount" at the top, and a "Hide Others" and "Quit Disk Utility" button at the bottom left corner. The scene then transitions to the macOS Utilities screen, which presents options such as "Restore From Time Machine Backup," "Reinstall macOS," "Get Help Online," and "Disk Utility." The "Restore From Time Machine Backup" option is highlighted, indicating that the user has a backup of their system that they can restore. The video maintains a focus on the computer screen throughout, with no visible people or environmental details beyond the software interface.

The video begins with a display of the macOS Utilities screen, presenting options such as "Restore From Time Machine Backup," "Reinstall macOS," "Get Help Online," and "Disk Utility." The "Restore From Time Machine Backup" option is highlighted, indicating the user's intention to restore from a backup. The scene transitions to the "Transfer Information to This Mac" screen, where the user selects "Time Machine Backup" as the source for transferring data. The current wireless network is shown as "TP-Link_5334." The next frame confirms the successful completion of the data migration with a "Migration Complete" message, accompanied by an icon of a computer with checkmarks, signifying the successful transfer of data. The video concludes with a view of the macOS system preferences, displaying various icons for settings such as General, Desktop & Screen Saver, Dock, Mission Control, Siri, Spotlight, Language & Region, Notifications, Internet Accounts, Users & Groups, Accessibility, Screen Time, Extensions, Security & Privacy, Software Update, Network, Bluetooth, Sound, Printers & Scanners, Keyboard, Trackpad, Mouse, Displays, Sidecar, Energy Saver, Date & Time, Sharing, Time Machine, Startup Disk, and Profiles. The environment throughout the video is a dark background, focusing on the macOS interface and its functionalities.

The video begins with a view of a computer's system preferences window, displaying various icons and options such as General, Desktop & Screen Saver, Dock, Mission Control, Siri, Spotlight, Language & Region, Notifications, Internet Accounts, Users & Groups, Accessibility, Screen Time, Extensions, Security & Privacy, Software Update, Network, Bluetooth, Sound, Printers & Scanners, Keyboard, Trackpad, Mouse, Displays, Sidecar, Energy Saver, Date & Time, Sharing, Time Machine, Startup Disk, and Profiles. The cursor hovers over the Startup Disk option, indicating an intention to select it. The scene transitions to a Startup Disk window, where the user selects the "Macintosh HD" disk, which contains macOS 10.15.7. The window provides instructions on how to restart the computer in target disk mode, allowing it to be connected to another computer using a Thunderbolt or FireWire cable and used as a hard disk. The video concludes with the Startup Disk window still open, showing the selected disk and the available options to restart or enter target disk mode.

The video begins with a computer screen displaying the 'Startup Disk' selection window, where the user has chosen 'Macintosh HD' with macOS version 10.16.7. The window provides options to restart the computer or enter target disk mode, with a note explaining the latter's functionality. The interface is dark-themed, featuring a search bar at the top right and a lock icon at the bottom left, indicating the need for administrative privileges to make changes. The scene then transitions to a plain gray background with white text that reads, 'Hope this helped? Leave a comment LIKE & SUBSCRIBE,' encouraging viewer engagement. The video concludes with this call-to-action message, maintaining a simple and direct visual style.
